newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - Nov 29.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - Nov 29.

text.p: Boeing Co might hire McDonnell Douglas Corp to supply it with commercial aircraft design, test and assembly services, the Wall Street Journal reported.

- Music video network MTV Networks of Viacom Inc wants to get computer on-line services to pay multi-million-dollar fees or risk having their users blocked from viewing the network's site on the World Wide Web.
- Cardinal Health agreed to buy Owen Healthcare Inc in a stock swap.
- L.A. Gear Inc plans to slash its U.S. work force to about 140 from 310 people and take charges as it moves to address its continuing losses.
- Long-distance telephone companies are raising their basic rates by up to six percent before the holiday season.
- Volkswagen's Ignacio Lopez might resign to help the German automobile maker settle a dispute with General Motors Corp.
- Stroh's Schlitz Malt Liquor is the first brand to come under scrutiny in an investigation by the Federal Trade Commission into alcohol commercials on television.
- Prudential Securities executives might escape criminal or civil charges in an investigation into the sale of limited partnerships.
- Certain industry groups, governors and mayors are forming a coalition to block EPA's proposed new national air quality standards on small partical soot and ozone levels.
- The latest economic figures show the U.S. economy during the fourth quarter will likely perform the same as it did during the previous quarter.
- Canada has adopted new anti-smoking measures.
- Dutch aircraft maker Fokker faces almost certain death after faltering talks with Samsung.
- OPEC will not add to world oil supplies until at least the end of June.
- Gold futures prices have hit a near two-year low.
- U.S. bond prices ended higher despite negative economic figures as traders waited for more information on the U.S. economy's performance.
- Subprime lending companies that offer high interest loans to borrowers with questionable credit records are making initial public offerings at a very quick pace.
